This is my final president s message, marking the
end of my two year term of office.

These past two years have proven to be quite
interesting, largely because many of the challenges the
board has faced have been somewhat unexpected.

We have had to undergo a government-mandated
change of our operating bylaws, we have had to
reinvent Zhe CN Journal, and still we have made
progress in other areas.

When I first joined the board, it seemed strange to
me that the RCNA didn t have a single guiding budget
document. Apparently we did way back in time, but
that s only what I ve heard. What I do know is that we
didn t have one available. But we do now.

For that I have to thank Rob Turner in particular,
who put in hours and hours of hard work, Paul Johnson
who helped out with information and even managed to
restructure our books to match our new system, and the
board as a whole, who went through the budget line by
line in a marathon telephone meeting.

The new document will assist us in measuring our
progress and making financial decisions regarding our
organization. It was one of my goals two years ago, and
I m glad to see it done.

We have already made some changes to reflect our
new financial reality. We will be having more meetings
by telephone to save on meeting expenses, and we have
reduced costs in a number of areas.

There are also lots of people I should be thanking,
and at the risk of forgetting some names, I will try to
single out a few that come to mind.

I have already mentioned the board, and Paul
Johnson, but I can t say enough about how important
they are to the RCNA and to me personally.

I also need to offer thanks to my two vice-presidents.
Both Henry and Robert have been a source of help,
wisdom, and experience during the past 24 months.

I also want to thank Serge Pelletier, who has never
once refused a single request of mine for help. Lisa
McPherson is another one who needs special mention, I
sort of press-ganged her into the youth services job and
she has turned it into a real going concern.

Finally, I want to thank the folks at the Royal
Canadian Mint. They have been a solid supporter of the
RCNA for as long as I can remember, and have become
a key part of making our conventions work.

BY MICHAEL D. WALSH 
LM,#302
Charles Dean Moore (August 5, 1946 June 11, 2015)

Charles (Chuck) Dean Moore passed away
in the early morning on June 11, 2015.

The numismatic world lost one of its
greatest members when Charles Moore
passed away on 11 June at the age of
sixty-eight after a long, quiet battle
with pancreatic cancer. His impact
on the Canadian numismatic scene
is near legendary, so my purpose
in writing this is not to reiterate
his outstanding offering to the
hobby over much of the past half
century. That information is already
thickly spread through the journals and
records, and it will be repeated again in
the coming days throughout the hobby and
the trade.

My purpose, rather, is to talk about Chuck. He
was called Chuck by his friends, so that includes almost
everyone who knew him. His affable style engendered
friendship. He was always eager to share his knowledge
and often a simple question led to a wonderful, long
outpouring from an unbelievable depth of experience and
wisdom. He had a brilliant mind and an amazing memory
for numismatic detail that reflected his depth of interest.

I was extremely privileged to have spent a decade and
a half in very close association with him. One of his many
passions besides numismatics was great wine and fine
dining, which paralleled my own. As a relief valve from
the pressures of coin shows we were attending and the
auctions we were conducting, three or four dozen times
each year we would share great bottles in the finest
restaurants in each city.

We shared much more than wine and food. For many
years, as Directors and then as members of the Executive
Committee, we plotted the course of the Canadian
Numismatic Association, taking it from a dwindling
membership and near bankruptcy in the 1990s to a
thriving Royal Canadian Numismatic Association. As
I began my fledgling auction business, he advised me,
shared inside information and offered advice to enable me
to better compete with him.

We also shared stories from our non-numismatic
worlds. I could share with you stories he told me of his
verbally sparring with Cassius Clay. Boxing was another
of Chuck s great passions, but to relate his boxing tales

here would fill too many pages. It filled many
dinners and emptied many bottles.
We shared our thoughts, ideas and
aspirations. We talked about those who
had inspired us. Chuck s greatest hero
was his father, a World War Two ace
fighter pilot in the USAAF. Chuck
was born in Detroit, grew up there
and went to college on a football
scholarship. During the escalation
of action in Vietnam, his father told
him to drop everything and move
to Canada. Canada gained one of its
greatest numismatists.
Chuck worked for James Charlton,
then he set-up his own store in Toronto s
Queen Street in 1969. He met his wife,
Leslie in 1974 and they married in 1978. They
settled in Niagara-on-the-Lake and in the early
1990s they began a family with daughter Alexandra and
son Matthew. Thinking that there were better educational
prospects for their children in the United States, with a
signed draft-dodger pardon in hand, Chuck moved the
family to San Francisco Bay area of California.

He continued and expanded his Canadian company
from afar. He also expanded his voluntary work with the
numismatic associations in Canada and remained at the
forefront, leading and inspiring. I feel privileged to have
known him and J am sure there are many thousands who
share that feeling. He was a very inspirational man and he
will continue to inspire.

He leaves behind his wife Leslie, his soulmate for forty-
one years, and their two children, twenty-four year old
Alexandra and Matthew, who has just turned twenty-one.

AN UNRECORDED 1832 NOVA SCOTIA
COUNTERFEIT PENNY TOKEN
BY.IAN SPEERS
A  New  Variety Uncovered
While it is increasingly rare for something truly

new to come along in the domain of pre-
Confederation tokens, the author wishes to
report the discovery of an apparently unrecorded pair of
dies of 1832 Nova Scotia counterfeit pennies.
All varieties of 1832 Nova Scotia counterfeit
pennies noted to date relate back to three
pairs of dies, apparently permanently
paired to each other as no mules have
been recorded. Different catalogues have
identified separate sub-varieties based
upon composition, edge type, and rim
width, all struck from the same dies. For
the purpose of this article, the classification
of Courteau! will be followed, diagnostics of
which may be summarized as follows:

Co. 286: Roman numeral  I  in date
  upper serifs to both sides

Co. 287 & 288: Arabic numeral  1  in
date   upper serif to left only

Co. 289 & 289a: Defective  1  in date
  upper serif to right only

There are of course significant
differences in bust, thistle and lettering style
that further distinguish the respective dies, as
each was hand engraved. As these three different
varieties are not currently plated in the Charlton catalogue, 
sample images have been reproduced at the end of this
article for ease of reference.

The author has had come into his possession a piece
struck from an unrecorded pair of dies in the Nova Scotia
Counterfeit series, depicted above.

The specimen has a weight of 13.03 g, 201.2 gr, and is
lightly engrailed.

Of note, the die axis of the piece is en medaille / upright,
as opposed to the comage / inverted axis otherwise typical
of the Thistle counterfeit pennies.

The obverse of this specimen shows superficial affinities
with Co. 289, in terms of the engraver s handling of relief
and execution of the bust, but it is quickly distinguished on
closer inspection of details. Leaving aside the absence of
the distinctive  beavertail  ribbon behind the neck that is
diagnostic of Co. 289 (potentially caused by an injury to the
obverse die of Co. 289 during or soon after manufacture),
the letter punches are visibly different from Co. 289. While
all letters seem to show minor differences, the most notable
distinguishing point for the author is the letter  A ,
appearing more heavyset on Co. 289 as against
a more graceful and slim form on this piece.
Likewise, the bust reveals subtle
differences when compared to Co. 289.
The shape of the nose is notably different,
having a similar outline to that of Co.
287/288. The geometry of the drapery is
distinct, most obviously toward the back of
the bust: on the new specimen, the drapery
continues below the truncation of the bust,
while on Co. 289, it ends flush with the truncation.
The button fastening the drapery is similarly
distinguishable, with this piece having much
smaller beads around the central pellet than
evident on Co. 289. The laurel wreath
crowning the King appears to have 13
leaves on this specimen, as against 12 on
Co. 289, and the placement of the leaves
relative to each other is notably different:
among other differences, on Co. 289 the
central leaf of the cluster of three leaves at
the base of the head is partly overlapped by its
neighbours, while on the new specimen the central leaf
overlaps those adjacent to it. While the affinities of general
impression of this bust with the one on Co. 289 leads to a
strong suspicion that both were engraved by the same hand,

there can be no question that the new specimen s obverse is
a distinct, previously unrecorded die.

Similarly, the reverse originates from a die visibly
different from any previously recorded counterfeits.
The numeral  1  with a top-left serif would, on initial
diagnostics, point only to the Co. 287/288 reverse die, and
indeed the initial impression of the new specimen side-
by-side with Co. 287/288 leads one to suspect a common
engraver for both reverses. The letter punches may be the
same as those used on Co. 287/288. But an examination of
the thistle itself shows that the two are entirely different
pieces. The stem base on Co. 287/288 is over the numeral
 8,  while the new specimen has the same feature located
atop the space between the  8  and  3,  with the point
The CN Journal Volume 60

much closer to the  3.  The geometry
of the leaves of the thistle is notably
different. For example, if one looks
at the outer aspect of the left leaf, the
sixth point from the bottom curves
downward on Co. 287/288, upward
on the new specimen.

Stylistic affinities of this new
specimen in comparison with known
counterfeits suggest that it is the product
of the same issuers as the familiar
penny counterfeits, and must be placed
in that group. Given general collector
apathy to the counterfeit series, it seems
profoundly unlikely that this is a fantasy
piece fabricated at a later date from
false dies for imposition upon unwitting
collectors. It would seem most plausible
that the new specimen originates from
a fourth, previously unrecorded pair
of counterfeit dies. Accordingly, this
previously unrecorded pair of dies must
be added into the 1832 Nova Scotia
Thistle series.

Beyond serial numbers and signatures
Much of banknote literature related to
Bank of Canada notes 1s focused on

the variety of signature combinations
of governors and deputy governors or
specialized serial numbers. From time to time
this is supplemented by major errors such as the
$10 journey series notes printed on $20 journey
series substrate.

When viewed as a work of art the Bank of
Canada notes have lent themselves to some
interesting interpretations of the design. One
prominent example of this has been the  devil s
head  notes of the 1954 series. The notes caused
quite a controversy because, in the engraving of
the portrait, an area of the Queen s hair gave the
illusion of a grinning devil. Modifications to the
printing plates for all denominations were made
in 1956 to exorcise the demon (1954 Series)!
An illusion requiring a modification of printing
is extremely rare, and it probably has occurred
only once.

Most would agree that the devil s head illusion
was not an error in any of the processes related
to printing of banknotes but was a consequence
of something that had been incorporated in the
printing plate.

The nature of the printing of banknotes is
such that even when things are printed within
acceptable tolerances there 1s a possibility that the
final printed image may cause illusions and lend
itself to different artistic interpretations. It should
be noted that generally the printing tolerances
for Canadian banknotes are very tight to allow
very minute details to be printed accurately. One
needs only to look at the variations in weights
of the intaglio printing or the microprint of the
lithographic printing to appreciate the very high
quality of printing achieved in Canadian banknotes.

Art as a result of unintended design
consequences

In this article I wish to examine some interesting artistic
interpretations that are a result of out-of-register printing.
The focus here is not on significant errors but on things that
are probably within the printing tolerance. These may seem
innocuous at first but yet create enough of an illusion that
allows for different artistic interpretation of the image.

Out-of-register printing can have different meanings. In
traditional four-colour printing, registration 1s the method
of correlating overlapping colours on one single image.
Out-of-registration printing in this type of printing results
in a blurry or fuzzy image. Canadian banknotes are not
printed using four-colour printing. On the other hand final
banknote image is printed using layers of differing images.
Majority of these layers are printed using the lithographic
process. The portrait and other raised portions are printed
using the Intaglio process. Each image layer has its own
printing plate.

Canadian banknotes have been printed using as many as
nine printing plates (Bank of Canada 2006). More recently
one intaglio plate has been used on the face and at least
two lithographic plates each on the back and the face of
the notes respectively.

Out-of-register printing of Canadian banknotes
therefore does not result in a fuzzy image. However,
because the relative position of image from each of
the layers changes, it can create an unintended design
consequence to the meaning of the visual element of the
banknote.

Out-of-register printing can happen between the intaglio
layer and one of the lithographic layers, or it can happen

between two or more lithographic layers. There are other
out-of-register issues that can result which are related to the
positioning of other elements such as the hologram.

The focus of this article is on the out-of-register
printing between the intaglio layer and the surrounding
lithographic layer.
The halo effect

The portrait on the face of the frontier-series
polymer series banknotes is printed using the
intaglio method. The intaglio is printed after
the background is printed using the lithographic
method. A type of error that has been previously
reported known as ghost notes clearly shows
the background printing with the portrait image
missing.

Some interesting effects are created when
the portrait is not missing but is printed out-
of-register relative to the background printing.
The design of the notes is such that some of
the portrait area will bleed into the background
printing not leaving any white areas around the
portrait. However, in some instances out-of-
register printing will leave white spaces around
the top of the portrait creating a halo effect. Four
examples of these on $10, $20, $50 and $100
notes are shown in the images | to 4. So far the
author has not found similar examples in the $5
frontier series polymer notes.
The missing hair line

The design of the $100 journey series notes lends
itself to an interesting effect on the portrait due to
out-of-register printing. In this series the portrait
of Prime Minster Borden is facing right. The
image is intended to show a lock of hair on the
left of Prime Minster Borden s face beyond the
forehead (Image 5b). This is a very intentional
part of the design as can be seen in the image of
the watermark accompanying the note (Image
5c). The engraving was done by Czeslaw Slania
and the image of the engraving clearly shows the
lock of hair on the left side of the face (Bank of
Canada, 2006   page 111). However, the design
of the portrait and the surrounding background is such that
when the portrait is printed more to the right relative to the
background then the lock of hair disappears (Image 5a).
This would not be considered a printing error as the note
would be considered to be printed to acceptable tolerances.
Yet the design of the various elements creates a different
interpretation of the face of Prime Minister Borden as seen
in image 5a and 5b.
The painted nose

An interesting effect is created in the $5 Journey series
note. The design of the portrait of Sir Wilfred Laurier is the
only one of all the portraits of that series where the nose
line is at the edge of the portrait with no element of the
cheek showing to the left of it. Due to this design the nose
line directly borders the background lithographic printing
layer. In all other notes the design of the portrait is such
that the background borders the cheek. Typically there is a
little bit of a bleed of the portrait into the surrounding areas
particularly in the $5 journey series note. When the portrait
is printed to the right relative to the background it tends
to go on to the yellow-brown of the surrounding image
creating a coloured nose as seen in images 6a, 6b and 6c.
The earring

The design of the portrait on the $50 polymer note presents
an opportunity for the ear of Prime Minister Mackenzie
King to don an earring on the top of this left ear. The ring
is that formed from the Orion circles printed as part of the
lithographic printed image. The Orion circles are further
away from the portrait and would not be considered as part
of the background. However, the design is such that when
the portrait 1s printed higher and to the right, then the ring
will find itself on the ear on the portrait as seen in image
7a, unlike 7b. A banknote has been seen where that ring has
been completely behind the ear.

In some cases the portrait will hide some of the Orion
circles giving an impression of a different coat-collar
design.

This article has tried to highlight some of the
interpretations of Canadian banknotes which result from
relative position of the different design elements of the
banknotes. Because these types of printing variations
would be considered within the acceptable tolerance, these
conditions, in the opinion of this author, are not printing
errors. However, the situations are created because of
factors that are directly related to the design of the various
elements of the banknotes and could be avoided through
minor changes to the design.

BY ALAN ROY
#17134
Olympic Coins from Antiquity to the Present
In 1970, the International Olympic Committee
announced that Montreal would be hosting the

summer Olympics. The city had successfully hosted
the 1967 World s Fair and Mayor Jean Drapeau was
confident that they could put on another world-class
event. But the tax payers of Montreal were understandably
apprehensive. Would they have to foot the bill for this
expensive sporting event?

One of the International Olympic Committee s
requirements from the city was to provide a balanced
budget. According to that budget, about $250 million
would be provided by a commemorative Olympic coin
program. In the past other Olympic games had financial
support through commemorative coin programs, but now
many in government and the media were dubious about
the city s budget. They thought that $100 million was
a more realistic number.

Peter W. Broeker, the president of the Montreal
Numismatic Society at the time, began to appear on
CBC Television and other media outlets to clear up
this confusion. Because of seigniorage (the difference
between the manufacturing and material cost of a coin
and its face value), foreign sales estimates, and the
experiences of the Germans with their Olympic coin
program in 1972, Broeker was able to show that the
original $250 million listed in the budget was not only
correct, but even a little conservative.

He explained that using special coin issues to help
finance large events was not new. It was a tactic used
by many countries for hundreds of years. The Montreal
Numismatic Society prepared a public presentation called
 Olympic Coins and How They Can Help Pay for the  76
Games,  featuring colour slides and commentary written
by Broeker. Soon, local government, the news media, and
even the Olympic Organizing Committee were requesting
copies. Broeker decided to use the presentation as the
basis for a catalogue. The result, Olympic Coins from
Antiquity to the Present, was published in 1973.

The book focuses mostly on modern issues by
Olympic host countries from 1952 to 1972. Coins
issued by non-hosting countries are arranged in their
own chapter. There are brief chapters on the history
of the Olympic Games and early coin issues from
antiquity. The author admits that this section is not
detailed enough for his liking, and he promised to
expand it in the next edition. Unfortunately, a second
edition was never published.

The last chapter is titled  Olympic Coins Preview,
Montreal, Canada, 1976.  It details the plans for the coins
to be issued for the 1976 games. The first four coins of the
planned 28-coin series are described, as are the budgetary
machinations described above.

This book provides not only an overview of the
evolution of Olympic coins, but also insight into the
decision process involved in creating the Montreal
Olympic series. Some collectors may deride this series,
but love it or hate it, it is part of our numismatic history,
and getting an inside view can be educational. And finally,
did taxpayers have to foot the bill for this expensive
sporting event? Yes. The 1976 games left a $1.5-billion
debt that took tax payers until 2008 to finish paying.

BY JAMES R. BAKES

79. Three Coins in the Fountain

In 1954 composer
| Fae Styne and
lyricist Sammy Cahn

completed the eponymous
song for the movie  Three
Coins in the Fountain  in
a single hour and had the
Sinatra demo record ready
the following day. This became, besides an Academy Award
winner and huge money maker for the composers,
one of the iconic songs of Rome and created a
need for every tourist to toss a coin with his
right hand over his left shoulder and make
a wish over the Trevi Fountain.

The Trevi Fountain seen here
shows the immense marble wall that
forms the backdrop for this wish-
making. Nymphs and water horses
form the sculptural wall called a
 Nymphaeum  above the large pool
or  lacus  in the foreground. The whole
thing is called either a fountain or a display.

In ancient Rome every aqueduct had its
 display.  The Trevi is the eighteenth century
display for the ancient Aqua Virgo, finished
by Augustus in 2 BC, and renamed by
Pope Clement XII (1730-40) the Aqua
Vergine when his wonderful new
fountain was complete.

In  Nummus Matrix 55  we saw
a silver denarius of 56 BC, which
showed the Marcian Aqueduct built
by an ancestor of the moneyer L.
Marcius Philippus. Ancient Rome was
built on seven hills overlooking a river,
the Tiber. In the low area between the hills
was a swamp or marsh so the site was well-
supplied with water enough for all. It did not take
long for the small villages on each of the hills to grow and
eventually consolidate into a single large town. This put
pressure on the water supply in a couple of ways. First the
swamp was drained into the river, then the drain became
a sewer for the disposal of
waste (the Cloaca Maxima)
and the river (not a very large
one for so major a city as
Rome) became unsuitable
for drinking or bathing. A
new source of water was
needed and Roman ingenuity
and engineering skill developed that quintessential Roman
architectural statement, the many-arched aqueduct.
Remains of these immense structures can be
seen throughout Europe; the best being
that of Segovia in Spain and the Pont
du Gard in southern France which is
a triple arch. The water was brought
sometimes over great distances from
pristine lakes and mountain streams.
Not much of the aqueduct was built
on the dramatic arched structures.
Most was underground; tunnels were
dug, cisterns built inside mountains,
channels were gently sloped so as not to
create too strong a flow and waste the water into
the surrounding land. For sometimes hundreds of
miles these structures carried enough water to
meet the needs of the growing city. As it
entered Rome, usually above ground, its
arches provided convenient locations
for trrumphal arches to honour generals
and emperors. It ended at a water
tower called a castellum from which
it was distributed to fountains, bath
buildings and private houses and the
Nymphaeum. The castellum contained
a huge holding tank which ended in
three vertical pipes. The upper pipe fed the
private houses of the wealthy (most ordinary
citizens simply dipped their water from the lacus); the
middle pipe was for the public buildings and baths; the
lowest pipe provided water for the fountains or displays.

Sand and other particulate material was settled out in
special castelli previous to distribution.

In all, some fourteen aqueducts were built in the 600-year
period between 312 BC and AD 305. (One of the last was the
Aqua Severina finished by the emperor Severus Alexander
in 228. The ruins of its display are right across the road from
the popular Hotel Napoleon in the Piazza Vittorio Emanuele
II, in a space housing hundreds of Rome s famous feral
cats.) The aqueducts supplied Romans with more water per
capita than is used today by Torontonians, a remarkable thing
when you consider our showers, washers, dishwashers and
lawn sprinklers are factored into the equation. Of course the
Roman system ran constantly and a lot of overflow water
was used to clean out their sewer system so a large volume of
water was never actually used by the populace.

The As illustrated shows the central arch (the arcuato) of
the display at the end of the Aqua Traiani, the Aqueduct of
Trajan built in 109 to serve his new bath complex near the
Colosseum and to continue across the river to the area today
known as the Trastevere. The arched area can be compared
with that at the center of the Trevi, although the figure there
is standing. The figure is in all likelihood the Tiber, nearly
identical to a figure named as Tiberis on a sestertius of
Antoninus Pius (some have called it the Gentus or spirit of the
aqueduct). He reclines on his left elbow and has an urn tucked
there from which water pours into the lacus. On either side are
columns as in the Trevi while a line of rocks across the bottom
must represent the edge wall of the pool. Around is Trajan s
standard reverse legend SPQR OPTIMO PRINCIPI:
Number 5
July + August 2015
the Senate and people of Rome to the best Prince.

The obverse shows the emperor head right with slight
drapery on his left shoulder, wearing the laurel crown as he
did on Ases and sestertii. Around is the typically verbose
inscription, always the longest on any Roman imperial coin:

IMP CAES NERVAE TRAIANO AVG GER DAC
PM TRP COS III PP: Imperator Caesar Nervae Traiano
Augustus Germanicus Dacicus Pontifex Maximus Tribunicia
Potestate Consul III Pater Patriae. (To the emperor and
victorious general Nerva Trajan Augustus Germanicus,
Dacicus, chief bridge builder to the gods, with tribune s
power, consul for the third time, father of the fatherland.)
Whew. No wonder they used so many short forms.

Those wishing to visit the Trevi Fountain today would
be better to hold off. It is currently being restored after 300
years in the rain and now acid rain. It is undergoing a major
restoration and is nearly impossible to see. (When I was
there in 2014, it was surrounded by heavy wire fencing in
preparation for its present burial under cloth over scaffolding
to protect the workers.)

If it is on your  bucket list  to stand in front of the Trevi
and join Frank Sinatra, the Four Aces, Dinah Shore and Dean
Martin in a rousing chorus of  Three Coins in the Fountain 
you would be wise to put it off for a year or two.
